text: Dramatically lit by sunlight filtering down from the surf A dim shape, massive, threatening, swims towards us from distance. Then it divides -- what was one is two, and the shape becomes reality; two divers in Scuba gear swimming  side by side. They are wearing minimal rubber, considerin the cool New England waters: "Farmer John" wetsuits with off legs, assorted sport-diving paraphernalia, including expensive camera with a flash attachment. One motions "Down there," the other signals "OK, I see it and they dive deeper, into darker waters, where the shaft of sunlight pour into the depths, broken up by seaweed an floating vegetation into cathedral-like columns of  illumination.

The wreck of the working fisherman's boat "ORCA," formerl under the command of the late Captain Quint, deceased the four years. Buried in the sand near it, still connected by rusting st of cable, the mangled remains of a shark cage, glimmering with stainless steel highlights. A fitful flash of yellow from under a mossy beard -- a battered barrel, similarly  tangled. The divers, Bert and Ernie, appear. They're fascinated by the find, and Bert, with the camera, snaps a few flash sh The rapid sequence of flashes signals the presence of a m drive camera.
Distant flashes, obscured by vegetation in the foreground

Ernie is exploring the abandoned cabin; doors open and sh moved by invisible currents stirred by his passage. An occasional "Flash!" lights up the bottom as Bert conti snapping away souvenir shots of this local landmark.

Ernie floats up out of a hatch, sees the camera, and stri a pose, clowning for the photographer's benefit. A big ha f.g., motions him up into clear water for a formal portra He obliges. Now he floats in front of us, gently paddling his flippers to maintain vertical stability. One flash. Another. Then a large, dim movement in the b.g. Something's out there, moving towards us. Flash. It's bigger, bearing down like a train in a tunnel Flash! It's on us. Flash! Teeth? Blood? Flash! Blackness, Death.
The camera floats gently down and settles in the sand. A  dark red mist eddies by. A last weak flash.

Flash! An expensive cabin cruiser, the "Diver Working" fl fluttering limply in the breeze, is riding alone at ancho Flash! A distant lighthouse beacon winks at us. The boat  rocks in the ceaseless swell. On the stern, "Elizabeth T. - Newport, R.I." A long way f home...

A blue-and-white police jeep is bouncing over the sand. A figure in civilian clothes driving alone on some urgent  mission. It's Martin Brody, Chief of Police on Amity. The jeep slows to a stop, and he takes a flight of stairs leading to a concrete patio two at a time. A classical tr solo is playing in the background. Brody charges through door, then abruptly slows and starts moving warily throug hotel interior: The Holidome, a three-story extravaganza a motel, where some sort of formal ceremony is already in progress. A banner announces: "Grand Opening Ball -- Amit Scholarship Fund Benefit." Brody crosses under a High Sch band, arranged dance-band style on a balcony; the trumpet player, Polo, is finishing his solo, the assembled crowd  applauds politely. Brody is taking his place with some  dignitaries on the dais, as the presiding authority, Amit Mayor Larry Vaughn, begins speaking.

Thank you, Paul Lohman, for that  eloquent solo. Now, for that point  in the ceremonies where we formally  dedicate this magnificent resort- hotel complex, a worthwhile addition  to the recreational paradise we call  Amity.

Seated on folding chairs, wearing their good suits, sever of Amity's Selectmen, Real Estate Developer Len Peterson, and Ellen Brody, very chic. Brody slips into the vacant c next to her. The following is conducted in urgent whisper sotto voce, while Vaughn drones on.
Where the hell were you?
Late.
I can see that. Don't you know this  is a big deal? BRODY
Couldn't help it.  Hendricks over there... (he indicates his  deputy)
...still has the keys  to the jeep in his  pocket, and I couldn't  find the spares. ELLEN
Terrific. Act as if  you've been here all  along. BRODY
How'm I supposed to do  that? ELLEN
Look bored.

Brody settles into polite attentiveness, acknowledging a  wave from Hendricks, a politely bland young town cop in h idea of civilian finery. Hendricks is fussing with the ba on an attractive young lady in a bathing suit...
...And now, Tina Wilcox, this year's  Miss Amity, will cut the ribbon that  officially opens this luxurious new  hotel...
Tina (the girl in the bathing suit) escapes Hendricks'  attentions, and teeters on high heels towards the ribbon, while Phil Fogarty, the local photographer, snaps away.

Tina was selected from more than 20  of this island's lovely young ladies in the Miss Amity competition  held every spring, and she'll  represent Amity Island in the Miss  Massachusetts Competition in Worcester  next month. When she cuts this ribbon,  she will be opening our island to  growth, to development, to planned  expansion with full employment for  our thriving community.
Paul Lohman ("Polo" to his friends) is exchanging whisper with Lucy, a flute player nearby.
I don't think she's such hot stuff.
When are we going out? You and me?
Not tonight.
You going with Patrick?
Lucy nods, Polo shrugs, and turns to Jane, a girl nearby.
Listen, Jane -- you want to dance as  soon as we get out of these monkey  suits?
She nods happily, they whisper together, while we:
Martin and Ellen have been joined by their youngest son,  Sean.
Mom, Michael won't talk to me.
(to Ellen) Shouldn't he be at home?
Mrs. Silvera couldn't come.

This money tree, you may have noticed,  is made entirely of twenty-dollar  bills, donated by Len Peterson, the  builder of Amity Shores Condominiums,  as a gesture of goodwill towards the  community. $500 as a special gift to  the Amity township scholarship fund...
Applause from the crowd, Len takes a bow.
(prompting) Go ahead, Tina.
as she reaches out with the scissors. Something catches h eye, and she winks at her boyfriend, Ed Marchand, smirkin in the crowd. He winks back, and makes "Cut it" motions w his fingers.
Tina cuts the ribbon, and Tom Andrews, a local diver, pus a decorated float out into the pool; sparklers sputter,  balloons drop from the ceiling.
Thanks to Tom Andrews, of Amity Aqua- Sports, for contributing the special  decorations. And now, the Amity High  School band. Refreshments on the  patio, everyone...
The band swings into "Downtown," and the crowd gets up to dance, to eat, and to break into small groups to talk.
Ellen is dragging Brody over to where Len Peterson and La Vaughn, the mayor, are in conversation. They pass vignett Tina and Ed, Tom Andrews and Jane, Marge, other interesti Amity townspeople.
(seeing Peterson and  Vaughn) Do I have to talk to those two?
My boss and your boss. Sure.
Hello, hello. It went well, I thought.
Very impressive ceremony. Good speech.
Thank you, thank you. You know my  son, don't you?
He beckons over their heads to Larry Vaughn, Jr., a young man uncomfortable in his correct tie and blazer. They exc perfunctory greetings.
The speech was right on the money. (to Ellen) Be a love and make sure the bar's  open, will you?
He puts his arm around her, a little too familiarly for  Brody's liking.
(to Brody) Fantastic lady. Don't know what I'd  do without her.
Me neither.
(looking around) Y'know, Brody -- for the first time  in years it's worth putting money  into this town.
All of us thank you, okay?
Watch Sean for a minute?
And she hands Sean off to Brody, leaving him with an over active 10 year old, while she's gone.
Can I go swimming?
No. Find your brother, okay?
Sean nods and runs off, happy to have a mission.
He is talking to Brooke Peters, a mop-maned teen-ager wit pleasant face. Timmy Weldon, a grade behind, lurks nearby. A plumpish, c haired buddy, Andy Nicholas, is enjoying a cup of punch.
How old is your cousin?
Seventeen. She's a senior.
I'm not crazy about blind dates.
They're okay, if they got little  white canes and tin cups.
That's awful.
What the hell. (to Mike) Did your mom put all this together?
Yeah, it's her job.
Is she responsible for the punch?
No.
Good. It's terrible.
My cousin will be here tomorrow.
Great.
Sean finds them, and bursts into their group.
Michael, Michael, Dad said to find  you.
Okay, you did that.
Come on, Mikey, come on...
He tugs at Mike's sleeve; Mike allows himself to be dragg off.
Okay, okay. Got to go.
Andy and Brooke are left standing together, Tim moves in.
(to Brooke) Want to dance? (she shakes her head  "no") Okay. Later?
On her shrug, as she turns to Andy:

It's later; night has fallen, the band is playing its ver of "When I Fall in Love." Many teen-agers are dancing out the patio, some adults are dancing inside, the buffet is  ravaged, Timmy is watching Brooke, who's dancing with Pol Douglas Fetterman ("Doug") joins him, after asking Marge a dance and striking out.
Get a dance yet?
Nope.
Me neither.
Who'd you ask?
Tina Wilcox.
You're crazy. She's Ed's girl friend.
Doesn't hurt to ask. Sometimes the  most beautiful girls are the  loneliest.
That's a crock of shit.
I know.
Bob Burnside, a tall pal of Larry Vaughn Jr.'s, turns up their side.
Same tired old faces. You see Vaughn?
The mayor?
Larry Vaughn Junior? (Doug shrugs) If you see him, tell him I got a six- pack, a blanket, and the Brebner  twins.
He exits, on the prowl.
No class.
None at all. (pause) I wonder what the Brebner twins are  doing tomorrow night.
Can you take a little time out from  your busy schedule to dance with the  old man?
Why?
Because they're playing our song.
And sure enough, they are -- the band has turned to a Fif slow-dance standard: "I Wish You Love." Peterson approach
May I have this dance?
Sorry, I'm all booked up... (taking Ellen) Come, m'dear.
They slowly fox trot out onto the terrace. Both of them  nodding greetings to townspeople and kids -- everyone kno the chief.
Remember 1959, the Jersey shore?
And how. I thought you wouldn't  respect me.
I did, I did.
The music and the summer moon are working their magic.
Listen -- what are you doing later?
Fooling around?
Right.
He dips with her; they look up and notice Sean, sound asl on a bench.
Let's get the kid home.
Home it is.
He crosses to the sleepy Sean and hoists him with a grunt
(to the kid) You're getting a little big for this.

Sean murmurs sleepily and hugs his dad. Mike, dancing wit Marge, waves good-bye. The Brodys start to leave, passing bucket with a bottle of champagne still in it. They excha a look, nod agreement, and Brody boosts the bottle, sneak it out of the building while Ellen giggles.

Brody and Ellen are snuggling under the covers while earl morning light streams under the blinds. It's The Morning  After, and the clothes from the night before are scattere all over the room. Brody rolls against Ellen, spoon-fashi morning-horny.
Mmmm.
MMMmmmorning...
They start to move a little, then turn face to face. Outs their door, the sounds of little feet; Sean padding  downstairs.
Sean's awake.
Door's locked.
(kissing) Good.
Their bodies move under the blankets. There's a crash fro the kitchen. They stop for a beat. As they resume, little feet return.
The milk fell out of the 'frigerator.
(whispering) Put a towel down. And shh -- daddy's  sleeping.
Okay.
His feet paddle off. Brody and Ellen start to slide toget passion resumes.
C'mere...

Bigger feet go downstairs; Michael's up. The Brodys kiss, trying to ignore the sounds of spirited discussion betwee brothers over who's responsible for spilled milk. Then th sound of a car pulling into the driveway, and a horn beep
Mrs. Silvera?
Mrs. Silvera.
They try to kiss again, there's a door slam downstairs, a talk between the boys and Mrs. Silvera. The Brodys look a each other and break up laughing at the morning, and  themselves.
As Ellen and Brody, with the practice of 18 years of marr swing back-to-back, and put their feet on the floor, each their side of the bed, still chuckling, up for the day.
Need a ride?
As far as the office.

The police jeep is driving through the picturesque street Brody behind the wheel, Ellen and Sean passengers. It slo near the foot of the street, dockside, where a real estat office marked "Amity Shores Development, Leonard Peterson Pres." sits. Peterson's big Cadillac is parked illegally the curb. It has the Amity Shores logo on its side.
Some people.
What's daddy doing?
Writing a ticket.
Brody is out of the car, his pad in his hand.
Hey! That's my boss!
Better yet.
Peterson, in shirt-sleeves and a tie, hustles out of the  office
Wait a minute...
Too late, it's written.
Heck of a way to treat a taxpayer. (to Ellen) Don't you have any pull with the  chief, here?
Do I have to?
(taking the ticket) Better get a sales kit together for  after lunch. I'm taking some prospects  out.
Ellen kisses Brody, and starts in for her day's work.
See you later.
(to Brody) Can't we fix it up to get this made  into a green zone or something?
Len, pay the two dollars.
Peterson shrugs and goes inside his office. Brody's atten is drawn by some noise by the dock.
Hendricks and an old codger, Red, are working on Amity's  newest bit of police equipment; a blue power launch for  patrolling local waters. The boat is Hendricks' personal  pride and joy.
(to Red) Tie it off on your left. Your other  left!
As Red complies, Hendricks spots his boss.
Good morning!
(walking onto the  dock, Sean tagging  along) Aren't you off-duty?
Till noon. This is on my own time. (to Sean) Hi, Shorty.
I'm not short. I'm eleven.
There's a hoot from a passing boat horn. Sean waves happi
It has slowed to a halt in front of the police berth; it' scruffy working fisherman, back from the banks with a ful load. The Skipper hails Brody.
Yo! Chief!
What?
You got a gold-plater drifting in  the main channel. Big cruiser.
Whereabouts?
Off the Point. No running lights,  just a diver's flag.
(aside to Brody) Want me to run out there?
On your own time?
Happy to do it.
Then check it out. I'll be in the  office.
Hendricks nods, and starts the engine importantly.
Cast off your bow line. And your  stern line. Spring line...
While Red grumbles, Brody and Sean are walking up to the  street. Michael and some teen-agers are headed down to the dock.
It's Mike, Polo, Patrick, Lucy, Brooke, Ed and Tina.
Where to?
No place special. Just hanging out.
Sailing?
Mike nods.
Watch your kid brother, huh?
He gets into his jeep, leaving Sean with the teen-agers.
Bye, Mr. Brody.
The others ad lib appropriate greetings/good-byes, as Bro drives off in his jeep.
The Kids busy themselves with their boats while Sean hove around Mike, who's not happy at baby-sitting his kid brot POLO
Anyone want to sail to  the lighthouse? PATRICK
Machs nix to me. LUCY
Anyone got a spare  mooring line? Mine's  shot. TINA
I've got one...
Tina's in her boat, "Tina's Joy," a neat sloop. Mike is g over his "Green Machine," a sleek catamaran.
You're not going out right away, are  you?
Waiting for Andy.
I want you to meet my cousin.
I will, I will.
I want to go out with you. You need  a crew, don't you?

Before Sean can protest further, Mike spots his crew: And Nicholas, a round-faced, frizzy-haired pal, wearing a bat suit, and carrying some scuba gear from an early-morning  diving class. Marge and Denise, two other divers, are wit him, with their gear. They ad-lib "good-byes."
I don't need you. Andy's here.
You always go with Andy.
(to Andy) How was dive class?
Same as always -- glub-glub, bubble- bubble, stroke-stroke. There sure is  some weird shit on the bottom of the  ocean.
Shells and lobsters and stuff?
Mostly old garbage. Today we found a  '48 Hudson.
Do I have to play with the little  kids?
Yeah. Go on, beat it.
Sean mopes away while Andy and Mike get their boat ready sea.
Up on the street, where a pretty girl with a sexy face an provocative post-pubescent walk is asking him directions. He points down at the dock. The Girl, Jackie Peters, wave at her cousin, Brooke.
Brooke! Hey!
One of the boats has a portable radio going. It's playing some medium-hot salsa. Jackie does a couple of dance step on her way down the dock.
Who's that? Quick -- I'm in love.
I hope that's the cousin.
Over here. I want you to meet  somebody.
Lucky. Lucky, lucky, lucky.
As the four teen-agers come together in a tight quartet, music rocks up and we:
Later in the day, sailboats with bright colored sails and ornately painted hulls tack back and forth. Lots of chatt between boats, horseplay, splashing, and general good tim It's cruising, on water.
with Mike, Andy, Jackie and Brooke.
How fast does this go?
With the right wind, 15-20 knots.
What?
Real fast.
He sheets in, heeling the boat over in the stiff breeze.
Far out!
Jackie screams in excitement; for a city girl, this is mo fun than a roller coaster.
overtaking Mike's boat. It's piloted by Larry Vaughn, Jr. the Mayor's Son; with him is his good friend, Bob Burnsid
Coming up!
Gangway, Turkies!
It's immediately a race between the red boat -- "Sizzler, and Mike's "Green Machine." The Kids ad-lib -- "Faster,"  "Lookout," "Gybe, gybe."
We're carrying weight.
We'll take your supercargo.
Is that me?
That's you.
I've never been supercargo.
Donny and Denise's boat cuts in, stealing the Sizzler's a
Hey, get out of our air!
Want a passenger?
Denise hops nimbly from one boat to the other as Danny sa tight as a tick to the red cat.
Way to go!

The sailboats cutting up, cruising the harbor, the local  teen-agers partying with each other: --  Patrick and Lucy's Sol Cat, flying its hull. --  Susie's Laser heeled 'way over' in a stiff breeze. --  Polo and a pretty girl in his sloop, "Sea Witch." --  Timmy Weldon and Doug Fetterman playing catch-up in t respective boats, the Doughdish and the Inflatable. --  Marge in her Lightening, sailing close to Ed and Tina Tina's Joy.

Silent, green-blue depths. A diver, Crosby, working the  bottom, running a search pattern. Another diver, Tom Andr running close. They signal to each other, and make anothe pass. Follow Tom Andrews as he skims the bottom, near the wreck the Orca, half-buried in the silt. A diver's line runs up and

Bobbing on the surface are three boats: the Amity Police  launch, the deserted Elizabeth T., from Newport, flying a diver's flag, and the ScubaVue, a local diveboat operated Tom Andrews and his partner, Crosby; it has "Amity Aqua  Sports" lettered on it somewhere. Hendricks and Red are o the deck of the police boat, peering at the cruiser.
Rich or poor, it's nice to have money.
Figure they split?
Happens every season -- someone takes  off. Once we had a schooner for a  month while the owners went fox  hunting.
A sudden eruption in the water nearby startles them -- it Andrews, surfacing, holding up the underwater flash camer
This is all there is.
Crosby pops up next to him, shows empty hands.
If that's it, that's it.
The divers head for their boat, Hendricks fires up his en and we:
Brody is trying to reason with an indignant fat man.
I can't watch the news, I can't watch  a ball game, I can't watch movies --  all I hear is that rotten kid with  his rotten radio... "Breaker,  Breaker..."
I'll do what I can, but you're talking  about a federal jurisdiction...
(leaving in a huff) So call the FBI!
Black, two sugars.
Thanks. What else is out there?
One petty theft, one domestic  disturbance, and an exhibitionist.
I'll take the exhibitionist, you  handle the others.
Chief Brody? I want you to do  something about my first husband.
Brody is caught in the open.
Martin, you have got to demand that  Grace Kinney keep her shades down.
What about enforcing the "No Parking"  ordinance on Beach Road?
In a minute, in a minute -- talk to  Mrs. Prendergast, please... WOMAN (continuing)
Albert keeps coming  around when I'm with  gentlemen friends and  he throws mud on their  cars...
(to White Haired Man) Talk to me about Mrs. Kinney.
Her bedroom window faces my oldest  boy's bedroom, and she's teasing  him, dancing around in a towel, or  less...
Dancing?
Hendricks has entered, carrying the camera brought up fro the bottom by the divers.
Chief...
Hendricks. I want to go over your  reports and your Form 908.
They go into Brody's inner office; the uproar continues b the door, but it's calm in here.
I never heard of a 908.
I just made it up. It means, "Get me  out of there." (notices the camera) What the hell's that?
Diver's camera. Tom Andrews brought  it up from under that abandoned  cruiser.
Abandoned? It's a little early in  the season for that.
Rich people. Home port is Newport,  Rhode Island.
If I had a $100,000 boat, I sure as  hell wouldn't leave it anchored alone  in the channel.
If you had a $100,000 boat there'd  be an investigation.
Hendricks puts the camera in an informal "Lost & Found" b sitting in the office. Brody makes the mistake of opening the door, revealing the White-Haired Man.
Grace Kinney is driving my boy to  distraction.
Hendricks, get a description of that  dance.
(to Brody) Chief Brody? I want to talk to you  about my daughter... she's 15, but  mature for her age... WOMAN
Chief, I've been telling  Mrs. Prendergast that  it's no good just  talking about Albert,  she's got to do  something...
As Brody turns to deal with the mess, we:
Looking up at the surface, where a hull floats in silhoue against the daylight. There's a commotion, and a water sk drops into view. Then another one. Pale legs churn the wa
Off Amity Beach, a bilious green lap-straked boat is bobb in the water, the engine idling. Two girls are fooling ar the one in the water is Terry, the one driving the boat i Diane.
Did you ever see a dolphin?
Sure. They like to play. We may see  some today.
Great!
She fumbles with her skis.
Whoops, almost lost one. Can't play  with the dolphins without skis...
Ready?
Hang on, hang on... Okay, go.

Diane goes to the controls, and puts the engine into gear starting forward. Terry waves "okay," Diane opens up the  throttle, the boat surges forward, pulling Terry upright. A wake boils out from under her skis.

Ed and Tina are camped on a blanket, necking in the shelt of the dunes. There's a portable radio, a cooler with som beer, and some sandwiches -- a perfect afternoon alone. A the dune, behind them lies the ocean, where the girls' sk boat can be seen, raising a big wake. Tina disengages, an sits up, brushing sand out of her hair.
Take a break for a minute, okay?
Huh?
Tina stands, and looks out to the sea, where the boat is  towing Terry on the water.
Eddie, can we do that? (no reaction) Can we go skiing? We can use my  Uncle's boat. Eddie?
Next week.
With you, everything's next week. I  want to go skiing soon. Tomorrow?
Ed grunts non-comittally. Tina takes a beer from the cool and goes up on the dune to watch Terry and Diane. She wav to them, and to someone down the beach.
An old lady, Grace Witherspoon, is rocking on her porch,  also enjoying the view of young people enjoying themselve She acknowledges Tina's distant wave, and turns her atten back to the skiers.
having a wonderful time. Terry is good, criss-crossing th wake, showing off.
rushing through the water, waving, stunting.
Faster! Faster!
She waves at Diane, who leans over the controls, to coax  more speed out of the old engine.
following the skis effortlessly, closing in on the turbul wake.
Terry whipping along; a fin raises near her. She glances it, waves, thinking it's a porpoise.
Porpoise! Look! A dolphin!
The fin slides low in the water, heading towards her. She puts the rope around her waist, leaving both hands free.
Closing in on the wake, crossing it.

The fin cuts across her path. Too late to maneuver, Terry hits the looming gray back of the Shark. The skis bump, l the water, Terry takes a spectacular spill. The rope arou her waist tows her helpless through the water, gagging he preventing her from shouting. She flounders as Diane slow the boat to see what's happened.
turning back to see if her friend hit a submerged log or  hurt herself.
Terry! You okay?
Help! Help!
Okay, okay, coming...
She still doesn't realize the gravity of the situation -- she hasn't seen the fin.
hysterical, pulling herself hand-over-hand up the rope, t to get to the boat.
Closing in on the thrashing figure.
Screaming, as the Shark rises from the deep and takes her Suddenly she's gone, a swirl of pink froth marking the wa where she went under.
Looking around for her friend, suddenly panicky. She pull the rope hard, and tumbles backward as it comes up with  nothing on it -- just a cleanly bitten end.
(screaming) Terry!
Then the Shark appears, blood on its mouth, lunging up an butting the stern, jarring the engine loose. Fuel spills  from a ruptured line.
Help! God, help!
She throws things at the Shark, which slides back under t water.
Diane can be seen flailing in the boat, very distant scre floating across the water; at this range they sound like normal shrieks of teen-age girls having fun....

as the Shark hits from a fresh angle, this time taking a  chunk out of the boat, biting down with powerful jaws. Di hurls seat-cushions, oars, anything she can lay hands on. She fumbles desperately in a compartment, produces a flar pistol. She cocks it and fires point-blank at the shark.
The flare hits, wet fuel glistening on the water and skin the Shark explodes in a sheet of flame.
A last flash before the gasoline explodes.
No-o-o-o-o-o...!
A sheet of fire, she's in the middle, screaming, aflame, Shark forgotten. She falls into the water as the ruined b overturns and there's an oily explosion.
Ed and Tina look up as they hear the distant "crump" of t boat blowing up.
Mrs. Witherspoon looks up, startled by the sudden tragedy She gets up to go to the phone, indoors, and we:
The launch is anchored at the site of the explosion, offs Red is fishing up bits of flotsam with a boathook. Hendri is on the radio, talking to the shore.
I can't find anyone out here. They  must've gone to the bottom, or drifted  with the current.

He's on the porch of tile Witherspoon house, using his  portable walkie-talkie. Mrs. Witherspoon is waiting in th b.g. Nearby, we can see a sign: "BURIED CABLE: Call New Englan Light and Power Before Digging." The cable itself surface in a chain-link fenced enclosure, and climbs a power pole for distribution to the island. Ed and Tina are also ther having given statements.
There should be bodies. Witnesses  say two people; one in the boat, one  skiing.
(filtered) I told you -- nothing here.
Try dragging.
For how long? Current's moving  everything around, and it's getting  dark.
Stay on it. I don't care how long it  takes.
Brody turns to Ed and Tina, and takes out his notebook.
We heard this noise, like a 'boomp'  out there, and when we looked, there  was just this cloud of smoke.
That was the explosion. One minute  they were having a wonderful time,  the next, bang!
I don't know what could've done that.
Brody stares out at the quiet sea -- what's lurking under that calm surface?
Can we go now?
Brody's still looking past them, towards the ocean.
Chief Brody -- can we go? Please?
Oh, yeah. Sure.
As he gazes at the ocean, we hear the sound of a distant  siren, and
An ambulance, siren wailing and red light flashing, drive on its melancholy way through the picturesque town.

Hendricks has the winch in operation, the cable in his ha with big grappling hooks attached. The boat is lit by its powerful worklights. Hendricks heaves them out, watches a the current takes them, then puts the winch in gear, haul back.
How much longer?
Until we find something.
I don't care about the overtime, I'm  hungry. And cold. And most of all,  bored.
It goes taut with a sudden strain.
He sees it, too.
I think we got something.
Red moves to the winch, watching warily as it slows to a  near stall with the weight.
About damn time.
What the hell is it?
There's a strain on the cable -- it's pulling the stern o the boat down as it struggles with the weight.
Here it comes...
lit by the harsh worklights on the deck of the launch. Th cable from the winch is taut, pulling something up from t black depths. What? The coupling appears, then the hook, an oily cable.
Oh shit. Drop it.
What is it?
Power line.
Oh, great.
He hits the release on the winch, and the cable whines as spins out and settles back on the bottom. Red jiggles the line, trying to free it up.
It comes here from Cable Junction.
Untangle it and let's go -- We don't  need a blackout on the island.
(at the winch) Now you're talking. Let's get out of  here before we do find something.

The next morning, the Brody family is downstairs, each ge his own special breakfast. Mike gets cereal for himself a Sean, Ellen is cracking some soft-boiled eggs, Brody is  drinking coffee and smoking.
You have to smoke so early in the  morning?
It's good with coffee.
So's a donut.
I want Fruit Loops!
Eat Cheerios.
You eat Cheerios. I want Fruit Loops.
Eat Cheerios.
What're you guys doing today?
(indicates Sean) I don't know about him -- I'm going  down to the dock, maybe go sailing.
Every day?
What else is there to do?
You could work out at the beach,  make a few bucks for school.
Do I have to?
You'll have to make up your own mind  about that.
Where's my day book?
In the den.
Ellen passes them on the way to the den to look for it.
He doesn't have to work all the time,  it's his vacation.
Mrs. Silvera enters from the service porch.
Good morning -- everyone up early  today?
There's a lot going on.
He follows Ellen into the den.
Ellen is rummaging around the papers on the end table, lo for her book.
Why don't you take a half day and  clean this junk up?
Because, I'm in the middle of a  boating accident, I got only four  regular cops and one secretary, and  a Chief Deputy who is constantly  fiddling with the police boat. He's  another one.
One what? (she finds the book) Ah-ha!
Boat nut. What is it about this place  that makes everyone a freak for  boating?
It's an island. (she pecks him on the  cheek) Got to run.
She heads out the door for the office. Mike approaches.
I'm going.
What about tennis? Riding? Fixing up  old cars? Bartending?
Bartending? I'm 17.
Okay, not bartending. Why on the  water every day?
Because.
Look, humor the old man -- just be  careful.
(going) I'll be careful. I'll see y'later.
Mike passes through on his way out, nodding to Mrs. Silve who acknowledges his passage.  Brody is close on his heel
Don't go out if it's rough or  anything, huh? We've had a lot of  trouble.
Okay, okay.
The back door slams behind him.
Can I go with you today?
You stay with Mrs. Silvera, Tootsie.  Okay?
Sean nods, resigning himself to the inevitable.
(to Sean) You can come with me to the market.
All right.
I'll be at the office.
Mrs. Silvera nods, and pours Sean a glass of milk. Brody  sighs, and heads out the door. Sean calls after him.
Bye, Daddy. I'm going to be careful,  all day.

Sitting snug and ship-shape on Mike's Green Machine are M Andy, Brooke, and Jackie. They are heeled over in a brisk wind, making good headway; sailing nearby in the b.g. are Patrick and Lucy and Donny and Denise, in their boats.
(from her boat) Where're we going?
Oh, out a ways. Maybe the lighthouse.
The lighthouse?
No big thing, we'll see who's out  there, maybe picnic.
We got some stuff at the store. Ed  and Tina are going to be there.
Oh, sure, they would be.
What's the lighthouse?
It's an island, near here, with a  lighthouse. We sometimes hang out  there, you know...
Great. I got some wine.
She opens her big floppy bag, revealing the top half of a jug of Mountain Red. Brooke slides over to her.
(aside) The lighthouse is a make-out spot.
Now I really want to see it.
You going to fool around with Mike? (Jackie shrugs) Well, I'm not doing anything with  him.
She indicates Andy, who pretends great indifference.
Well, maybe I will, then.
Andy does about a triple take before he regains his cool. Mike concentrates on his sailing, Jackie grins an impish, vixen grin, Brooke shrugs.

spectacular view from the top of the old lighthouse, show ocean, sandy beach, some of the Kids' catamarans pulled u on the sand, other pleasure boats cruising in the b.g. Ed and Tina are running down the stairs, laughing.
Come on back up here!
Nope.
Give me back my hat!
Double nope!
where Andy, Mike, Jackie, and Brooke are camped around a  blanket listening to a portable radio. Ed and Tina run by
Why'd they decide to move?
Too hot in the lighthouse?
Too hot for those two? I can't believe  it.
Is there something I don't know about?
I told you, remember?
Oh, yeah. So why aren't they doing  it now?
There's a little round of giggling.
Maybe by now they are.
They're moving pretty fast.
He's cute...
running towards a dune and over it.

in f.g., covered with birds. Ed and Tina appear over the  crest of a dune, and the frame explodes in a flurry of  seagulls, suddenly disturbed. The whir and drumbeat of wi and the shrieking of the gulls is a jarring shock.
reacting.
Yech!
The huge hulk of a beached, decomposing dead whale, a few birds still pecking at scraps of blubber and entrails. Bi festering red holes mark its sides.

From the top of the lighthouse, we can see a group of  interested spectators, clustered around the whale like an at a picnic. A few more boats are beached and riding at a just off the shore, including the Amity police boat. Three Ants are walking towards the crowd, one of them  gesturing.
She's Lureen Elkins, a marine biologist from the Oceanogr Institute, and she's skeptical. Brody is the ant whose  antennae were waving in the long shot.
As soon as I heard about it, I called  you. This thing is big!
His arms indicate big.
After we've looked, we'll talk.
This is it.
He moves forward to clear the crowd. Some kids are poking the massive hulk with sticks. A tourist couple is snappin away with a Polaroid SX-70. The whole mess stinks, too.
Move back, please... back off...  open it up a little...
The crowd edges back, giving way to Brody and Elkins.
See? What'd I tell you?
Brody is holding a handkerchief to his nose as he approac the dead thing, indicating a huge open wound on the side.
Look at that!
First things first.
She produces a tape measure and gives one end to Brody.
From the tip of the snout, please.
Elkins is measuring the length of the creature. She calls off numbers to Hendricks, who is officiously writing it a down, repeating numbers as he hears them.
Length, 22 feet, 8 inches.
Come on, let's check the bite radius.
(cold) The what?
Bite radius. You know, the size of  the mouth?
The whale's mouth?
The Shark's mouth.
What shark?
Brody pitches his voice low, so that the crowd won't list
The shark that did this. It was a  shark, wasn't it?
We don't know that, do we?
But that's what we're here to find  out, right?
You don't tell me my job, and I won't  tell you about yours, okay?
I can't hear you if you're going to  whisper.
Can we go now?
He turns to join the kids as they slip through the crowd return to their blanket, ad-libbing good-byes.
(to Mike) You stay here a minute.
Oh, c'mon.
You heard me.
We'll be over by the lighthouse.
I'll be right there. Wait up.
They hang around, waiting for him. Elkins has reclaimed  Brody's attention.
Could be a shark. But maybe not.
Look, I know a little bit about  sharks.
Do you?
I know that this was probably a Great  White Shark. Car-cadon... Caradan...
He fumbles for the correct Latin.
(helping out) Carcharadon Carcharias.
That's it.
Okay, so that's it.
Is there one in these waters?
What makes you think there might be?
Because this big fish has been bitten  by some other big fish...
This is a mammal, not a fish.
Jesus, don't quibble with me. I want  to know if a Great White Shark did  this.
Probably.
That's it? Probably? Look, sharks  are attracted by blood, and thrashing  around...
And sound.
(this is a new one) Sound?
Sound. Like sonar, or radar. They  home in on irregular sounds, unusual  sounds, any rhythmic low-frequency  vibration.
So there's one around here.
Not necessarily. These wounds could've  been inflicted 30 miles out to sea,  or more. None of them are immediately  fatal. Currents could've carried the  body 10 miles further.
(chiming in) We got a helluva tide this month.
Could you just keep that crowd back,  please?
(fidgeting) Pop...
You stay right here. You're going in  with me.
As Elkins examines the whale, calling her observations to Hendricks. MIKE
We came out in my boat. BRODY
Andy can sail in it. MIKE
I got a date! BRODY
She'll understand. MIKE
She won't.
The Kids have moved a little closer to hear what's going between father and son.
I don't want to discuss it.
Elkins crosses to Brody.
It's either a Great White, or another  killer whale.
Can't you tell?
Not when it's like this. This animal  has been ashore for 10, 12 hours,  and drifting for a day, at least.  Every little nibbler in the sea's  taken a bite.
Look -- can Great White Sharks  communicate? Send out signals, or  something? You know, take revenge,  sense an enemy...
Don't be ridiculous -- Sharks don't  take things personally.
Dad, please...
Brody turns on him.  This at least, is something he can d something about.
No more sailing. You come back with  me, and that's it.
Why me?
Because I say so.
I'll tie up at the town dock, don't  worry, man.
See you later, Mikey...
Later, bye... (ad lib)
Vaughn and Brody enter, walking through the spare, empty  town meeting hall, towards the conference table. They are alone.
I'm showing summer rentals. We got a  helluva season going.
We have got to talk, and we have got  to talk alone.
We're alone.
Larry, I don't know how to say this,  but I think we got a shark problem.  A real one.
Vaughn stares at him, then unlocks the door to his privat office -- "Mayor" -- and leads Brody in.

Small, expensively furnished in antiques, with a few symb of Amity boosterism cluttering one wall: a photo of the b featuring a shark tower; an architect's rendering of the Holiday Inn, some charts and graphs showing upward progre a few stills of businessmen's luncheons, plaques, awards, etc.
Are you serious?
Of course. Look -- I've got some  missing persons, fatalities, evidence  of a large predator...
No one has seen a shark -- no fin,  no bites, nothing. Be realistic.
I got a feeling. I have to act on it --  you can understand that, can't you?
Of course I can, but can't it wait?  These things cost money, and this  town doesn't have much money.
We have to do something.
We have done something -- hell, we  damn near went broke putting up a  shark watch tower on the beach --  it's the only one in 2000 miles,  y'know.
I know, I know...

And I stood by while you told the  people from Ramada and Marriott that  if they put up a hotel they'd need  $800,000 worth of steel net around  their beaches! In New England? We  all lost on that one.
It's still a good idea.
Martin, when we build up our tax  base a little, you can have everything  you want; right now, the town's broke.
Please, Larry -- there's good reason. Those water skiers...
(interrupting) A tragedy. But that was a boating  accident; no bites, no sharks, nothing  but a boating accident.
Two of them are still missing!
There's always deaths in these waters  that never turn up. Are they all  shark victims?
Maybe they are!
Brody's overstated his case, and he realizes it.
Bullshit.
(shouting) Bullshit? I'll give you bullshit --  there's a dead whale out there with  bites all over it!
(shouting back) What am I, an ass? When you called  me, I called Elkins, and her bosses.  Nothing she saw is proof of anything.
Someone has to do something.
(back in control) Don't push it this time. If you do,  it won't turn out the way you want,  I guarantee you that.
The two men study each other for a long moment. Then,
I've got to get back to work.
He holds the door for Brody, who walks out as Vaughn lags behind, locking up his sanctum.

Brody is alone in the jeep, headed for the safety of home and family. He drives past the town's billboard: it's cov with an architect's rendering of the Amity Holiday Inn. T sign reads: "WHEN IN AMITY, ENJOY THE HOLIDAY INN." Plastered across it is an added streamer: "NOW OPEN." Bar visible underneath are older notices: "UNDER CONSTRUCTION and "OPENING IN JUNE." As Brody passes the sign, he impulsively swings off the m road and heads down towards the beach.

Brody is on restless patrol, checking the water's edge as continues on home. As he drives along, he sees: a clambak some teen-agers in a group, necking and dancing; and a fe solitary surfcasters and fishermen. The beach is deserted, the sun is setting, and Brody and jeep have the sand to themselves. It's then that he sees  something:
A big bow section of a ruined, burnt boat is bobbing in t surf just off the beach ahead. It's a piece of the  waterskiers' boat; Brody heads towards it.

As Brody slows his jeep just short of the water, and gets out to look at the flotsam. His shoes get wet. He backs u onto dry sand, then tries to edge closer to examine this  object. It bobs up and down in the surf; Brody makes "Get in here motions. The junk resists.
Come on, give a guy a break.
No response. He takes off his shoes and socks, and rolls his trouser legs. A silly sight. He wades into the water  after it.
Come on. Here boy. Come to Poppa...
It eludes him, and he flounders after it. A big wave brea across his crotch.
Hoo! Cold!
He's almost there, it's just beyond his reach, he's got i he's lost it, he has it again, it's slippery...
(ad lib) Come here. Come on, Sweetheart. You  bastard. A little closer... Here  y'go...
Then, he's got it ---
(exultant) Gotcha!
As he grabs the ruined wood, and pulls it towards him.  Suddenly, the mass of wreckage breaks apart, and somethin lunges out of the mess and into Brody.

Brody is suddenly pinned under a soggy charred horror; th gory remains of Diane, burnt beyond recognition,: flesh p away, discolored, charred, ruined by days in salt water. screams, and scrabbles in the wet sand, trying to get out the dreadful clutches of the half-human thing he's dredge from the water.
Extricating himself, puking, retching, splashing water on his face, washing his hands frantically, just behind him, The Thing lying on the sand, a gruesome joke played by th sea.

Macro close on a pharmaceutical bottle of Sodium Cyanide, from which a syringe is withdrawing a healthy dose. Follo the syringe and reveal Brody, working at his desk in the  deserted office. He is injecting the deadly chemical into some jacketed .38 hollow-point ammunition; a dozen cartri are lined up in neat array, he is filling the last of the sealing the points with wax from a burning red candle. Th radio scanner is monitoring the local police band: routin reports faintly in the b.g. -- a slow night in pre-season Amity.
As a sound at the door makes him look up. He hides the od gear as Hendricks enters, starched and crisp in his unifo
Chief?
In here.
I missed you at the funeral home.  Santos said you were here.
You didn't miss much. Christ, what a  mess.
Positive I.D.?
The woman passenger on the boat that  blew up.
Oh.
There's an awkward pause. Brody sees the box with the div stuff sitting where it was left earlier.
What about that camera?
What camera?
That one -- from the wreck. You  brought it up, did you look inside  it?
Hendricks' guilty look confirms he didn't.
Well, what the hell -- might be  something worth seeing. Take it  somewhere and see if there's film in  it...
(catching on) If there is, develop it!
You got it.
The Deputy rummages in the locker, happy to be on the tra
I know just where to go.
Not the drugstore!
Of course not, They're closed. Phil  Fogarty's place. He'll do it for me.
The drugstore's closed? What the  hell time is it?
Nine-thirty, ten maybe.
Shit -- I'm late for dinner... Close  up, okay?
And he runs for the door, the speed-loaders with the Cyan bullets safely in his pocket.
(at the door) Oh yeah -- I'm expecting a long  distance call, very important. Give  them my home phone.
Right.
Brody pats his pockets to make sure the speed-loaders are safe inside, then exits. As Hendricks watches him go,
Brody's jeep pulls up, and he gets out, beat. He is slouc towards the door when he hears the phone ring inside. He  perks up, and starts to move faster.
Ellen is on the phone in the den as Brody enters the hous The Kids are on the floor in front of the TV, playing an  electronic video game that pings and beeps softly under t following.
(into the phone) Thank you. I'll tell him.
For me?
(hanging up) Sort of -- Matthew Hooper is aboard  the research vessel Aurora, presently  in the Antarctic Ocean, and won't be  in radio range until half-past next  spring.
Damn.
He starts upstairs, casually concealing the towel-wrapped package of gun and ammunition.
Is Hooper coming to dinner?
Not till next year.
He goes upstairs, Ellen waits a few beats, then follows h
Brody comes up the stairs and goes into the bedroom, wher he carefully puts the gun in the bed table. Ellen finds h
Oh, hi -- How was dinner?
Oh, perfect -- a 75 per cent family  affair. Where were you?
(getting up) Santos' place.
They both know what that means -- the morgue. Brody goes  into the bathroom and starts scrubbing his hands compulsi
Ellen follows Brody, watches as he washes under too-hot w
Oww!
Careful. What's wrong?
Nothing.
Nothing, huh?
That's what I said. Is there any of  that hand cleaner stuff?
Use the little brush there. Why were  you at Santos'?
Found one of the missing victims  from that boat deal.
Oh. Want to talk about it?
No.
Terrific.
Mike comes up the stairs, and is starting into his room w Brody spots him; Sean is just behind him.
Michael.
Yeah?
You want to come here a minute?
Mike shrugs and crosses to his father; Sean whizzes past into his room.
Hi Dad.
Hiya yourself.
What is it?
He expects something: this is a formal audience with the  Head of The House.
I got something for you to do  tomorrow.
I kind of had plans...
Sailing? (Mike nods) Forget it. You're beached. Grounded.  No more boats.
Hey, come on...
No backtalk! I spoke to Upton, at  the beach, and he's got a job for  you there. You can work until school  starts.
All summer?
He wanted a job, he's got one. I  want to see that boat out of the  water by tomorrow night.
We see Sean's door opening as he peeps into the hall to s what the fuss is about.
It opens a few inches, he looks out at the grownups and h brother, decides he wants no part of this, and quietly cl the door.
Dad, please...
Tomorrow night. Out of the water.
Mike silently storms into his room, not-so-silently slamm the door as he exits. From inside the room, loud rock mus muffled behind the door -- an expression of teen-age  rebellion.
Not so loud!
The music lowers its volume. Brody turns to go into the  bedroom, to take his shoes off, to go to bed...
I know what you're going to say.
Do you?

(on the bed) In the city, it happened all the  time -- some Kid o.d.'s on a rooftop,  top, a drunk gets cut in pieces under  the Brooklyn local, old people die  alone in shitty apartments and three  weeks later someone calls the cops  because of the smell and the flies.   Call the cops. What are we, immune?
It was bad, wasn't it.
The goddamn smell is always the same. (he shudders at the  recollection)
Are you going to be able to sleep?
Yeah. I think so. (he raises his voice) Mike! Keep it down, for chrissake!
Ellen gets up, and quietly closes the door. The upstairs  hallway is empty, the doors closed. The Brody household  compartmented and closed for the night.

The familiar striped cabanas flank the white sands; there a crowd of midweek seasonal tourists and locals oblivious the tall steel tower that dominates the beach. A classy van outfitted for passengers pulls into the park area, followed by Vaughn's Cadillac; the parking attendan waves them into a preferential area, where they disembark Vaughn, Peterson, Ellen, and some more prospects, includi a woman named Bryant and her daughter, Renee.
This is the town beach; the  development naturally has its own  private access, but I wanted you to  see the concession area. Look at  that sand -- like sugar!
He scoops up a handful of the fine powder. Ellen directs attention of the photographers.
During the summer, the sun sets right  there... (she points) Over the water. Beautiful.
(to Ellen) I'll say hello for you.
Ellen nods, preoccupied. Vaughn strolls away, headed in t direction of the cabanas. Mary Nichols, a local Selectwom emerges from behind the counter of one of the concessions
Hello -- selling some more of the  good life?
A piece here, a piece there, it all  adds up.
Your husband's been here all morning.  What's he doing?
(good-naturedly) His job.
Michael Brody, dressed in township workman's coveralls, i repainting some flaking woodwork. Sean is happily mixing  paint. Vaughn joins them.
Your dad got you working?
Yeah.
He continues his chore, without enthusiasm.
I'm helping.
You know where your dad is?
Up there.
He points at the tower.
Oh, for Christ's sake.
He crosses briskly to where Peterson is finishing.
And if you have any questions about  recreational possibilities, Ellen  Brody here will be happy to answer  them.
Len, can I see you a minute?
Peterson excuses himself and joins the Mayor.
I think we got a couple of live ones.
Brody's riding his tower.
(looking up) Oh, shit.
sweeping the water with binoculars, restless eyes trying scan everything, a grim watchman high over the heads of t unseeing crowd.

Larry Vaughn, Jr. comes skimming in close to the surf. Bo is handling the sheets, Larry is giving young Jackie sail lessons -- at the moment he's showing her how the tiller  works.  He's on her like glue.
This is fun! Can we go faster?
(to Bob) Trim.
Bob does, Larry trims the main, and the hull lifts.
Yay!
She snuggles in Larry's arms. He waves to someone.
That's my dad!
Jackie waves without seeing.
Vaughn waves back, preoccupied. Near him, Mike Brody look up, his face grim, jealous, and now a little nuts. He spl paint onto the wood with angry abandon.
(to Peterson) Wave to my son.
(waving) How the hell do we get him down from  there?
Maybe nobody will notice. Let's get  them back in the bus.
Mrs. Bryant approaches them, tugging her daughter.
Renee wants to know what that man is  doing way up there?
He's, ah, watching. A lookout.
For what?
(a precocious little  girl) It's a shark tower. I saw one in  Florida. He's looking for sharks.
It's an observation platform. That's  our Chief of Police. He's just  checking it.
Normally, it's used for, ah, bird  watching. Nature observation. Weather  measurements, that sort of thing. (a little desperate) Ellen, we're running late!
Okay. Folks, if we could get back  on, we'll show you the country club,  and stop for lunch...
At the mention of lunch, the prospects, all hungry, begin flocking back into the van. Peterson herds them along.
The country club has an 18-hole  course, putting greens, and twelve  tennis courts...
still scanning. His body suddenly tenses. There's somethi out there. He mashes his binoculars to his eyes, trying t get a better look.
Through the binoculars, something big and black, moving u the buoys and into the swimming area.
He can't believe it. But looking past him, we can see it  with the unaided eye: a seething dark mass, moving throug the water towards the unprotected bathers.
(screaming) Out of the water! Everyone out of  the water!
No one can hear him. A few little faces look up, unable t catch what he's saying. He starts climbing down the ladde shouting.
Get out of the water! Tell everyone  to get out! Now! Out of the water!
reacting.
(recalling another  panic) Oh, my God...
What the hell is he doing?
Oh, no!
Looking up, startled at Brody's sudden panic.
The dark mass almost on top of the swimmers, who are star to look around. Most of them are oblivious to what's happ on shore.

as his feet hit the sand and he starts running for the wa fumbling for his gun and the speed-loader with the cyanid bullets. He is bumping into people, knocking little kids  over, stepping on blankets and umbrellas, a madman.
Out of the water! Now! Everyone!
Running too, half-stumbling, half-believing, remembering.
Moving after her husband, while Mike steadies Sean, holdi the impulsive kid back.
(seeing something) Martin! No!

The gun is out now, he's trying draw a bead on the shape the water; chest heaving, he tries to steady his shaky gr People see the gun and scream, throwing themselves flat o the sand, running, some of them going into the water.
No! Don't go in! Stay out! Stay clear!

He fires. Again. Bullets ricochet off the water, howling  towards the horizon. Real panic now. Four more shots. Reloading, ejected rounds falling bright into the sand, B on his knees, fumbling with bullets.
standing on his platform, shocked, watching the Chief of  Police fumbling with his gun.
It's bluefish! It's a school of  bluefish! Chief! It's bluefish!
It is bluefish -- a tight mass of them, churning up the w in a dark, dense group. The swimmers look around, confuse by the shots and excitement.
What's going on?
Fish! Anyone got a net?
Someone get me a rod and reel!
Laughter defuses the tension in the water; bathers move  around, some getting closer to see the fish, others leavi the water to join friends and families on the sand.
where Brody is now standing, panting, coming down as a cr collects at a safe distance around him: Ellen emerges fro group that includes Vaughn, Peterson, and Nichols.
Sorry. I'm sorry. False alarm...
Curious crowd murmurs as they watch this lunacy. Brody  realizes he's fired his weapon, that spent shells litter sand at his feet.
Okay, it's all over, go on, it's  over. No trouble...
Ellen joins him.
It's okay. It's over...

Brody drops to his knees, fumbling for the cyanide bullet in his gun, trying to put things in order, scrabbling in sand for the empty shells. The crowd is curious and embarrassed. Some turn away, oth drift back to their blankets, talking about what's just  happened, others stare rudely. Brody is coming apart.
It's all right, everything's all  right...
Sean emerges from the crowd, and helps his daddy pick up bullets, Ellen moves to disperse the rudely curious.
Let's go, everyone... Mrs. Bryant,  Len, please...
He sees Sean, his eyes fill with tears, and he grabs the in a fierce hug.
A hurriedly called meeting of the town's Selectmen is in  session: Vaughn, Peterson, and three others: Kaiser, an o man still in his grocery clerk's apron; Sansom; and Nicho the woman on the beach.
Brody's a good man.
Nobody says he isn't.
You should've been out there. You  should've seen him waving that gun,  like a maniac. There were shots fired!
He thought he had a good reason.
But that's not rational behavior!
That's what I'm saying!
How many people were there?
Hundred! Literally hundreds. What  are they going to say about us?
(to Vaughn) Larry, I'm a businessman, trying to  make a buck like anybody else.
So? So?
So it can't be done like that. The  man's a menace, plain and simple.
Look, what am I supposed to do? It's  done, it's over. We have to deal  with the consequences.
That's what we're here to do.
All right. Let's go into my office,  where we can have a little privacy.
as the selectmen troop into the cramped quarters. Vaughn  deliberately closes the door as they find seats around th room.
I believe we have a quorum, and  informally, I suggest we call this  meeting an executive session and  dispense with minutes...

Brody, alone, is sitting at his desk, morosely studying a little gold statuette of a pistol marksman. What's done i done, and Brody is trying to figure out how to live with The phone rings, is answered in the other room. The buzze sounds. Brody picks up his end.
Polly, no calls, please... (she insists) Okay, okay. (he punches a button) Hello... Phil? Fogarty? What  pictures... I'll be right down...
He slams down the phone and gets up to go, suddenly posse with a purpose.
Amid the equipment, clutter and proofs, some shots of the holidome opening, drying on wires. Phil Fogarty, the indi fat man and town photographer, is locking the door behind impatient Brody.
I don't know what you did, but that  kid stopped. I haven't heard one  peep, not one 'breaker breaker' for  days. Believe me, it's a pleasure...
You said something about a camera.

Sure, sure -- Jeff Hendricks brought  in this camera, see, from underwater,  and I didn't know how to get it open,  but my brother-in-law, in Montauk,  he works at a hi-fi store, and they  sell cameras, so he...
(interrupting) Did you get any pictures?
Well, yeah, I did, that's the funny  thing. You can't tell much from the  negatives, I was going to blow 'em  up. Here's a test I did...
He holds out an 8 x 10 proof, Brody snatches it from him.
Brody stares down at it. Sure enough, the ghostly outline of the Orca, underwater, a diver on the deck making a ges at the camera.
Oh, Jesus. That boat...
Not bad -- that's a real fast lens,  probably 1.4. Look at the diffusion,  though...
What else you got?
Let's see -- you got a minute?
Come on, Phil, don't jerk me around.
Okay, okay -- stand over there...

He gestures, Brody steps to one side of a table with some big enamel pans for washing and developing prints. Phil  switches to a red light, and takes some printing paper,  putting it under the enlarger.

--  Enlarger light going on. --  Timer ticking, the hand turning. --  Quick negative images: water, boat, diver, hand, boat again, tantalizing fragments of the opening sequence proj on the enlarger's flat base. --  Hypo and Developer sloshing in a pan under Phil's han --  Brody staring down.
Quietly gaining contrast in a pan of developer, a print o what at first looks like seaweed, then is unmistakably th grinning jaws of the Great White.
A quick nightmare vision of Brody, alone in a sinking Orc trapped in a battered cabin interior; a Great White crash through the glass, its head huge as it lunges.

The close-up detail of this otherwise blurred and unreada photo is unmistakably a detail from a very close view of snapping jaws of a Great White; if you hadn't seen it as memory, it would make no sense at all. For Brody, the mea is all too clear; for anyone who's never seen the monster face-to-face, it's nothing.
(shaken) That one there. That one...
Phil's hands, holding plastic tongs, gently slosh the pri in the bath. The shark's features are indistinguishable f the surrounding detail.
Brody walks into view, and starts up the steps into the t hall, already lit from within. He's carrying a large enve
The Selectmen (Kaiser, Sansom, Nichols), Len Peterson, an Vaughn are seated informally around the big table.
(looking up) Speak of the devil.
Brody enters, carrying the envelope with the photo.
Thank God you guys were all together.  I got something for you. Proof!
Martin, this is kind of an official  meeting
Perfect. Look at this ---
He fumbles with the envelope.
Chief -- the Board of Selectmen has  a question only you can answer.
(preoccupied) What?
Is Jeff Hendricks qualified to fill  in as an interim Chief of Police in  your absence?
Temporarily? Uh... sure... The  question's out of left field. Why  are they asking?
So Jeff could handle things? He knows  the routine, he has the authority?
Yeah. Why?
It came up during the meeting.
Look -- I just got this from Phil  Fogarty. It was in the camera  belonging to the missing divers. It  proves I was right, all along.
He throws the picture down in front of them. They bend ov to study it, pass it around, look at it. KAISER
Seaweed?
I don't know -- what is it?
It's a shark! A Great White! Jesus,  it's right there!
He snatches up the photo.
Just as before, an ambiguous pattern of light and dark; n proof of anything without Brody's inner vision.
It's nothing I can see.
waving the picture.
What are you all, blind? It's a shark.  Look -- teeth, jaw, gills.
Is that what it is?
You're damn right that's what it is.
I'm sorry, I just don't see it.
Sansom and Kaiser agree, ad lib, "That's nothing..."
Martin, it could be anything.

(exploding) What the hell does it take to make  sense to you numbskulls? Jesus, it's  right there in front of you. I know  what a goddamn shark looks like,  I've been through it, don't you  understand? I've seen this sonofabitch  before!
The Selectmen look at each other in the face of Brody's  agitation. Tempers are running high.
What have you seen before? This is  nothing. Seaweed. Mud. Something in  the lens.
My ass!
Be reasonable, please...
(to Vaughn) Forget it, he won't listen.
There is nothing to discuss.

(blowing up) Will you listen to this man? Will  you just listen to him? (to Brody) You really caused a panic on a public  beach, you shoot up the place, God  knows who could've been injured --  what if somebody decides to sue us?  That could ruin us.
Is that what it is? Dollars? Money?  I'll pay for it. Take it out of my  salary.
You don't make enough.
Maybe I don't make as much money as  some bullshit rip-off artists around  here, but I don't work the same way.
What's that supposed to mean?

It means I don't like all that grab- ass and heavy breathing with my wife,  it means I know who's out to screw  me here, and it means that I know  something none of you know because  I've been there -- and I don't want  to go through that horror again.  Ever!
There's a long pause.
Martin, could you wait here for a  few minutes while we make up our  minds about something?
Go ahead, whatever it's worth.
The Selectmen file into Vaughn's office, leaving Brody al in the room. The last one in the door very carefully make sure it's tightly shut. Brody sits alone at the table.
They are sitting there, deliberating.
I won't mention his personal attack  on me.
I've never seen him like this.
And Hendricks is qualified, you heard  that from his own mouth.
We made a motion and it was already  seconded.

(official) Very well then. It is moved and  seconded that Martin Brody be relieved  of his duties as Chief of Police,  his contract with the township be  terminated, and that Jeff Hendricks  be appointed Acting Chief in the  interim. Those in favor?
All the hands go up.
Anyone opposed, or is it unanimous?
Vaughn's hand goes up, the sole dissent. They stare at hi
I'm sorry, but I respect his  convictions. The motion is carried.
He goes to the door, and opens it.
Martin? Could you come in please?

The police jeep pulls up and stops; although the engine's shut down, Brody still sits quietly inside the car. Then hand appears at the window, and he drops an empty beer ca onto the lawn. Clink. After a while, he drops another beer can, then another, u the "clinks" tell us he's polished off a six-pack on the home. Not too steady on his feet, Brody climbs out of the car and starts for the door to his house.
Ellen is working at her desk in the den. She is looking  towards the door, expectantly -- it's been an unusually l pause between car arrival and husband arrival. Brody ente
Hi. I closed a sale today, without  Len. That's $1200 commission, if the  papers go through.
That's great.
Sean's asleep.
That's great too. Gorgeous.
He takes a long look at her.
You look about 22 years old sitting  there. Like you were doing homework...
He goes to join her, bumping into some furniture in the d lit room. Ellen has a beer and sandwich half-finished on desk; Brody takes a healthy swallow from the beer.
(sensitive) What's wrong?
Ooohh, nothing. I just got fired,  that's all.
He tosses the photo sloppily on the desk.
What?
What'd I say?
That you were fired.
Then that's what I meant. Fired.  Canned. Out on my fanny. The Selectmen  just made Hendricks the new Chief of  Police. Just like that.
Because of today? The beach?

(expansively) No sweat. A blessing in disguise.  Back to the city, you can go to  Bloomingdale's without waiting six  hours for the ferryboat... we're  surrounded by water here, you realize  that? Me, surrounded by water...  Ridiculous.
Stop that! We're not going any place.  You love it here. Tell me what the  hell happened!

Showed them the photo, showed them  the goddamn Shark, big as life. They  didn't see it. Not like me. Not like  the poor son-of-a-bitch who snapped  this li'l picture... He's out there,  somewhere... I shot off my gun, shot  off my big mouth, so they fired me...
(studying the photo) Honey, this is nothing... I don't  know what it is. What did they...

(going on) ...Everybody wants the job. No one  wants the authority. Except Hendricks.  Fine. He can go out there in that  precious boat, and when he looks  whitey in his big mouth he can just  call me. Call me in New York... tell  him to kiss my ass...
(seeing his pain) They have no right to treat you like  that. You've given them everything.  For four years, you've protected  this town, the people on this  island...
Fired me! (at Ellen) I'm not a hysterical man. I'm  responsible. I know what I saw...
I know you did...
I try. Goddamnit, I tried... Now,  I'm tired... I can't keep fighting  it... I'm too tired... I'm... I'm...
Brody's slipping under; the beers and the day have finall overcome him. He slumps in Ellen's arms.
You're drunk is what you are...
She eases him onto the couch, tucking a comforter over hi inert shape.
Take it easy... Easy...
Sean comes down the stairs, sleepy, in his pajamas.
Is dad home? I heard something...
He comes into the darkened den.
Shhhh. Go back upstairs. Daddy's  sleeping.
Sean finds the photo, and stares at it idly.
What's this?
Nothing, sweetheart. Seaweed.
She takes him by his sleepy hand and leads him out of the room, leaving Brody tucked in on the couch, dead to the w

This is the Amity teen-ager's hangout -- a newsstand and  pinball arcade with a minimal refreshment counter where s drinks and submarine sandwiches are dispensed. A jukebox blaring some n.d. rock music. Present are Donnie, Doug, T Bob, Larry Vaughn Jr., Brooke, Marge, Denise, Jane, Andy, and Mike. The boys are passing around hot-rod van and cus boat magazines; the girls are looking at Silver Screen, T Beat, People, and Time. Andy and Mike are at the counter, splitting a sandwich.
(holding a book) That's what I want -- a gaff rig.
Gaff rigged? Why not a staysail  schooner? Go anywhere. Look at this --  the Mayan, an Alden schooner.
Hey, Mike -- I saw your dad over at  the town hall.
I know.
(innocently) Did he really freak out at the beach?
I don't know.
Hey, it's all bullshit. Anyone want  to play pong for money?
No one does. There's a bustle at the door, and some coupl enter from the movies: Patrick and Lucy, Ed and Tina, Pol and Jackie. There are a lot of ad-lib greetings;
How was the show?
Yech.
It was okay.
I'd rather go the lighthouse.
Who wouldn't.
Anyone want to go the lighthouse?
Now? At night?
Nah. Tomorrow. Early, spend the day.  My folks left two cases of beer in  the garage.
Is it still there?
Nope. Got it in my boat.
All-right.
Let's go for it.
There's a general ad-lib agreement to organize a day's sa picnic.
Mike, you going?
Why shouldn't I?
I thought you might still be painting  the restrooms at the beach.
Laughter from the gang.
Anyone want a coke or anything?
They break up into pairs and trios, some going for the so fountain, others hanging out by the magazines.
I'd like to go out to the lighthouse  with you.
I'm not sure I can.
It'll be fun, come on!
Maybe you and Brooke could come over  to the town beach...
No way. Everybody's going sailing.  If you don't want to take me, just  say so.
That's not it. My dad told me not to  go.
You do everything your parents tell  you?
No.
Good. I'll be on the dock at eight. (to the gang) Eight o'clock, everybody!
They ad lib agreement.
(aside to Mike) I really want to to be there. (to the crowd) Who's bringing the wine? And who's  got a quarter for the box?
Brooke takes Mike aside, as Jackie goes to the jukebox. Larry is right there with a quarter, standing next to her they select a tune.
She just likes to tease. I think she  really likes you.
Great.
Some rock music starts, and we:

Ellen is asleep under the covers, Brody, still in his clo from the night before, is sprawled on top; obviously he's stumbled upstairs sometime during the night. There's a no down the hall, from Mike's room. Brody stirs, but doesn't wake up.

Mike is holding a lamp that's almost fallen -- the noise just heard. He's almost dressed, but not quite satisfied  with his image in the mirror. He takes off his clean shir and checks a more comfortable, worn shirt. A brief sniff make sure it's okay for another day, and he puts it on; h tiptoes to the hall, where a noise stops him in his track
Mike is frozen in his part-opened bedroom door. Sean's do opens, and little Sean, also fully dressed, comes sneakin out.
(whispering) You're going out.
Yeah.
You're going sailing.
Maybe.
Take me.
No.
(louder) I want to go with you!
Quiet!  Shhh!
(even louder) Michael...
Okay, okay. Close your door.
Sean does, and happily tiptoes with exaggerated stealth t Mike; the two of them start downstairs.
Michael and Sean are walking away towards the road into t
Brody emerges from the bathroom, dressed in sweatshirt, a cutoffs: no uniform today. He starts downstairs, stopping only to look into Mike's room. It's empty.
Good morning, America...
A grin crosses his face -- "My son, the Don Juan..." He g downstairs.
Brody enters from upstairs. He heats coffee. Ellen enters dressed for work. He pours two cups.
What're you going to do today?
Turn in the car. Clean my desk,  explain things to our sons, then  maybe get shit-faced and punch your  boss.
I'll give notice.
Don't rush into it -- we may need  the income.
She pours the coffee, they drink it for a moment.
Mike left early. Couldn't wait to  make out. Must be a morning man.
Ellen and Brody sip their coffee quietly for a few moment Mrs. Silvera arrives, carrying groceries.
Morning. Anything special today? ELLEN
Sean's not up yet. You  know what he likes,  just some Fruit Loops  and milk. No candy.
Frankie. He's my cousin.
Frankie. Okay. Ask him if he needs  an apprentice.
Brody and Ellen are at the door.
Have a nice day.
They leave.

The Kids are into their boats, fitting out for a day of  recreational offshore sailing. Mike and Andy are readying his Tornado, while Sean gets in the way. In the b.g.,  Hendricks can be seen puttering around on the Amity polic boat.
If you're beached, why are we doing  this? For practice?
Yeah.
Then why are we futzing around the  dock? We can make a few bucks working  at the beach.
Sean knocks something over, Mike snaps at him.
Look -- if you're going to get in  the way, you can just go home.
I'm not in the way. Andy, am I in  the way?
You're always in the way.
Marge joins them, scooping Sean up.
This guy giving you any trouble?
Put me down!
Put him down in the water.
(to Sean) You want to go out in my boat?
Yeah.
Would you take him?
Sure.
You've just made someone very happy.
Marge and Sean go over to her Lightening. Brooke and Jack come down the dock, dressed for sailing.
Mike! Are you going out?
Maybe.
I thought you were grounded.
I can go out if I want to.
You can?
You going to the lighthouse?
Why not?
I could give you a dozen good reasons.
(to Andy) Shut up.
Okay, okay, don't say I didn't remind  you.
Is there room on your boat for all  of us?
Mike looks: Andy, Jackie, Brooke, himself... Timmy moves sensing the chance of a lifetime.
Well, we're pretty crowded, and I  don't know when we're leaving...
Timmy makes his move.
I've got room.
Great. (to Andy) That's okay -- I'll go with Timmy.
You will?
Sure.
And she walks towards his boat, looking back for him to  follow. He's dumbstruck by his sudden good fortune.
Fan-tas-tic!
He runs to join her, untying mooring lines like crazy; th together again at last for the first time. Andy is left  shuffling with Mike and Jackie.
I'm ready.
And she plops down in Mike's boat, ready to be taken.  Anywhere.
Come on, you guys.
Well, I don't know...
Jackie flashes him one of her pouty little smiles. Why br one heart when you can break two? Or more?
Please come with us?
Mike is glaring. The message is clear, if unspoken.
For me...?
What the hell. For you...
Andy joins them.  Mike casts off, while Andy helps, and J sits there, looking cute.
watching what's going on.
I thought you said she was going  with us?
Let's just go sailing, okay?
(casting off) Want to talk about it?
Want to swim home?
Bob gets the message and shuts up. The Sizzler fills its  sails, and points out of the harbor.

Lots of day-sailing Kids, a few bigger, adult boats, some working fishermen and sport fishers; a typical recreation boating mix. The Kids are finding the same general direct pointing out of the harbor.
-- Sails being trimmed. --  Brooke and Timmy, staring into each other's eyes as h sets a course straight for the lighthouse. --  Larry, lifting a hull, almost losing Bob.
The Kids' boats, in a loose bunch, slipping out to sea.
The dive class boat, isolated near the channel, a group o Kids in wet suits and tanks assembled with three adult  instructors: Tom Andrews, Crosby, and Sparky.
Andrews and his assistant instructor, Sparky, are address the class, when Mike and Andy's "Green Machine" sails by, close.
Hey! Nicholas! You're supposed to be  in class!
Today I'm staying topside. You dive  for me!
I'm going for lobster.
Great! Find one for me.
With butter, if they got any...
Andrews dismisses them with a good-natured wave.
So long, turkies.
He turns to his class.
Sparky will take you down today. If  everyone's got a buddy, we'll drop.
The class dutifully lines up and starts going in, while i the b.g. the Kids sailboats head out to sea. Andrews' two partners, Crosby and Sparky, get ready to follow the clas over.
(to Andrews) Let's get some dinner.
He goes over, Andrews following. Sparky is with the class signaling "Down;" they submerge like clumsy seals.
The class, paired up, is drifting down; Sparky offering  encouragement as they descend. Andrews and Crosby are alr disappearing, swimming away with strong kicks.
as they go over the edge of a shelf and drop into darker, deeper waters. Crosby checks his depth, his watch, looks  around...
far above him, the class, going about their business. Below him, murk, depth, and suddenly, a big lunker bass. Andrews sees it, too.

Assuming Crosby is following, he takes off, following the big lunker. Crosby, hung up in some minor equipment probl misses seeing him go. The two men are separated. Follow  Andrews as he twists and turns after the bass, going deep losing him in the rocks, suddenly rounding a boulder, and meeting, almost face-to-face, horror:

The Great White Shark, taking the striper in a single gul it's looking up at Andrews with one glassy doll's eye; it turns to face him directly, and we see the scar; ugly, re and black, charred flesh from jaw back on the right side, eyes and teeth gleaming like raw bone in the massive, unc face. Andrews' mouth clamps violently on his mouthpiece, then g wide as he screams in fear into the water. Finning backwa he ditches his weights, gulps for air, and yanks the cord his safety vest. It balloons out, and pulls him up, surgi towards the surface. The mouthpiece, useless, falls away  from his lips. Eyes closed, hose dangling, Andrews hurtles upward, holdi his breath in a final, fatal panic, passing a startled Cr
look over at the rocketing ascent. What's wrong? Sparky  signals "up," and they begin to carefully follow him towa the surface. Crosby's already surfacing.
Andrews is on his side, bloody froth on his lips. One of class is clinging to his legs, trying to arrest his  convulsions. Sparky is holding his shoulders, trying to  administer mouth-to-mouth.
Get us in! For Christ's sake, get us  in!

In his arms, Andrews writhes, pain knotting his limbs. Behind them, in the water, the fin surfaces, and casually turns towards... the ocean. The Shark is headed for the s And for the now distant Kids in their sailboats, dotting horizon in their familiar bright colors.
They are alone. In the middle distance, the rest of the K sails can be seen, headed for the lighthouse in the dista The Sandpiper's sails are luffing, they're making no head
You want to tack, or just leave her  pointed up like this?
(snuggling close) Just like this.
What about sailing?
The tide's running. It'll take us to  the light.
It'll take us to Budapest if you're  not careful.
Ed is lashing the rudder as they continue to drift with t current.
First things first.
He fumbles in a cooler chest, produces a bottle of wine.
What about the others?
They'll be there when we get there.  Might even have a fire started.
What're we going to do in the mean  time?
I dunno. We'll think of something.
He pours the wine into the two paper cups.
But first, a little juice...
And second?
(kissing her) Mmmmmm.
(resisting) Wait a minute. Promise me something.
Anything. Anything.
That you'll put down a blanket. I've  got black and blue marks all over my  butt, and my Mom's getting uptight  about them.
You got it.
And he fumbles for a blanket in a locker, thumping and ba gear around as he rummages for it. Tina sips wine content satisfied to wait.
The Sandpiper's hull, alone above us, as the Shark rises  with dreadful certainty, attracted by the erratic sounds Ed's hasty search.

The terrible fin breaks the surface, about 20 yards out,  then dips and disappears. Then, impossibly fast, the enti Sandpiper is lifted from underneath by a powerful surge, the Shark lunges up against it from below, an unseen horr Ed is knocked over the side, into the water.
as he breaks the surface, shaking the hair out of his eye trying to orient himself, finding the boat. He starts to  swim for it, Tina extending an arm to help him climb aboa

He has barely taken two strokes when a powerful force tak him from below the surface, rushing him towards us throug the water. Tina screams. Before Ed can react to the pain, is slammed face first into the boat. His jaw breaks, bloo smears his nose and lip. His hands grab the wooden-cap rail with a death-grip.
Tina is staring down at the water, terror-stricken; Ed's  arms and head are f.g., as he locks onto the boat with  desperate hands.
Ed's hands on the rail, knuckles white, an iron grip. Wit awful finality, the force pulls down, and the wood shatte and splits away as Ed's hands are pulled down and under b the awful force.
her mouth working silently, unable to scream, staring dow at the blood and froth on the water, swirling in a grim e under her, the Sandpiper rocking gently in the diminishin swell.

On the way to the lighthouse, but away from the harbor, t Kids are sailing in fairly close order: The sloops (Polo, Timmy, Marge) heeled well over in the stiff breeze, the f cats (Mike, Larry, Donny, etc.) skimming around, tacking  more often, faster and more maneuverable.
Faster! Faster!
Coming about...
She ducks under the boom, handling the jib sheets with ea familiarity. They come about and scoot off on a new tack.
Reading the wind, trimming sail expertly, competent and a
(to a near-by boat) Great day! I think the wind's going  to change...
He comes about, she slides into him, he holds her to stea her, she snuggles into his arms. True love, at last... He thrilled.
In his inflatable, poking slowly along. Marge passes him, Sean hooting with glee.
Coming up.
Slowpoke! Slowpoke! Marge is faster!
I'm getting new sails, then watch  out. Just a question of modifying  the rigging!
Jackie, Mike and Andy, clipping along, Larry Vaughn and B in the Sizzler nearby. Mike lifts the hull, Jackie squeal in delight.
Wheee! Faster!
How fast is enough?
I want to go faster!
Hang on...
He trims his sheets, the cat heels more, one hull flying, Andy and Jackie clinging to the trampoline.
Larry is carefully adjusting his tiller, Bob senses what  he's doing.
You coming up on him?
You bet. Hang on...
They gybe sharply, running up behind the green cat.
Coming up! Give way!
Like hell! We're on the starboard  tack!
Running close to each other; very tight two-by-two.
Don't let him pass. Faster!
Mike and Larry silently fight for clean air, racing. Wate splashes over them.
My hair's getting wet!
So's mine.
He veers onto a less dramatic tack, sparing Jackie's hair Larry and Bob speed by, yelling.
